980

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

and the Hindu community. He had a free college for students; he left a great reputation as a scholar and died at a great age in 1806.

Though JagannÄtha exercised great influence in moulding Hindu Law in Bengal, his work has been held from very early times not to have any binding authority in Western India.1836

  1. Conclusion

In the foregoing pages most of the classical works and the most prominent writers on DharmaÅ›Ästra during a period of about twenty-five centuries have been passed in review. The number of authors and works on dharmaÅ›Ästra is legion. All these numberless authors and works were actuated by the most laudable motives of regulating the Aryan society in all matters, civil, religious and moral, and of securing for the members of that society happiness in this world and the next. They laid the greatest emphasis on the duties of every man as a member of the whole Aryan society, as a member of the particular class to which he belonged and very little emphasis on the privileges of men. They created great solidarity and cohesion among the several classes of the Aryan society in India in spite of their conflicting interests and inclinations and enabled Hindu society to hold its own against successive aggre ssions of foreign invaders. They preserved Hindu culture and literature in the midst of alien cultures and in spite of bigoted foreign domination. There is no doubt that the authors on dharmaÅ›Ästra in their desire to evolve order out of chaos and to adjust and harmonise the varying practices of people with the dicta of ancient sages were guilty of the faults of raising hair-splitting arguments, divisions and sub-divisions and also of thinking that religious rites and formularies were the be-all and end-all of human existence. But living as, most of the later writers did, in the midst of aggressive and violently unsympathetic cultures and rulers and possessing no powerful central government that sympathised with their ideals, they were driven more and more to revolve within their own narrow grooves and could not see far in order to regulate society in a free and buoyant spirit. In spite of

1536

Vide Vinayak v, Lakshmibai, 1 Bom, H.C. R. 117 at p. 124.Brief Note on Works from Kamarupa

981

these defects, the work done by the writers on dharmaÅ›Ästra should excite our admiration and entitles them to the regard of all those that are interested in the study of the vicissitudes of Hindu society for thousands of years,

Brief Note on Dharmasastra Works and Writers

from KÄmarÅ«pa (i, e. Assam )

Raghunandana in his Smstitattva several times mentions * KamarÅ«piya-nibandha'. For example, in ( vol. I) Tithitattva 587 p. 86, PrayaÅ›citta p. 555, MalamÄsa p. 820; (vol. II ) Ekadasi tattva p. 102. The Tithitattva (p. 76 ) says that the Smstisagara quotes the MatsyasÅ«kta' and the PrÄyaÅ›cittatattva (p. 535) says that the Smstisagara is KÄmarÅ«piya-nibandha. It may be noted that on pp. 530 and 532 of the Prayascittatattva (vol. I) a work entitled SmstisagarasÃ¥ra is cited and verses of Bá»‹had-Angiras are quoted from it. The Nirnayasindhu under the topic of

maháº§navami' (p. 186 of Nir, edition of 1935) mentions Kama rÅ«pa-nibandha and quotes the same verse as is quoted by Raghunandana (in vol. I. p. 86 ) as from SmrtisÄgara, a Kama rÅ«piya nibandha.

On the occasion of the 22nd session of the All-India Ori ental Conference held at Gauhati (Assam ) in January 1965 a

PrÄgjyotisa souvenir' was published by Dr. Maheswara Neog (Local Secretary of that Conference). Among the several papers contained in that souvenir, Pandit Manaranjan Sastri, Principal of the Sanskrit College at Nalbari (Assam ), contributes (on pp. 91-114 ) a very interesting and informative paper on the KÄmarÃ¼pa School of DharmaÅ›Ästra. In the brief account that I present here I can refer only to a few salient points.

1537

The verse E-TT: 19 VE TERIT: T ga ai a9 n ET faÅŸini #T HET40T I quoted by Raghu (vol. I) Tithitattva, p. 86 and on p. 23 of the à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤° of à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤®à¤¹à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤¦à¤° com piled ip sake 1308 ( 1386 A. D.).

982

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

One of the early and famous writers from KÄmarÃ¼pa is NilÃ mbarÃ cÄƒrya. He is credited with the authorship of four works viz. (i) AmÅ›aprakÄÅ›ikÄ, a Com. on the ViÅŸnupurÃ¥na; (ii) SraddhaprakÄÅ›a or ÅšrÄddhabhÄsya; (iii) Kalakaumudi (on the appropriate times for religious acts and rites ) and (iv) CandraprabhÄ - a digest of Smsti material dealing with sins and prÄyaÅ›cittas to be performed for the removal of the effects of sins. He tells us little about himself. At the end of the Sraddha prakÄsa he tells us that his father was a learned man named Sarkarsana and gave himself up at the confluence of the Ganges with the ocean. He learnt the Å›Ästras from his father. He holds the view that the word mÄsa means by itself the lunar ( cÃ ndra ) month, while other Kamar Å«pa writers held and hold till these days the view that mÄsa means Saura ( solar ) month. As Sula pÄÅ†i in his Durgotsavaviveka, and Govindananda in the Suddhi kaumudi (p. 275 ) mention him, he must be earlier than about 1375 A. D. and as he mentions the Kalpataru, JimÅ¯tavÄhana, GovindarÄja, Bhavadevabhatta, he must be later than about 1225 A.D. In his ÅšrÃ¤ddhaprakÄÅ›a ( when treating of adhimÄsas' intercalary months) he says that he himself has observed about intercalary months, certain irregularities and mentions Å¡ake 1199 (i, e. 1277 A. D.) as the year in which the irregularity occurred. So NilÃ¤mbara must have flourished between 1240 and 1300 A. D.

The KÄlakaumudi is mentioned several times by Raghu nandana e. g. vol. I, Tithi pp. 73, 129, 141 and (vol. II) in EkÄdasitattva p. 51. A work called Smstisagara is quoted several times by Raghunandana e. g. ( in Vol. I) Tithi p. 76 ( three verses are quoted as from MatsyasÅ«ktÃ  cited by SmstisÄgara ), Tithi p. 86 (Smstisagara is a Kamar ipiyanibandha ), PrÃ¤yaÅ›citta-tattva p. 474 ( quoting Devala ), Prayascitta-tattva p. 554 cites Smsti sÄgara quoting Yama and Matsyatantra, (vol. I. p. 555 ); Ragu nandana also quotes Smstisagara (vol. I. Prayascittatattva pp. 530, 532 one verse on each page quoted from Bá»‹had-Angiras ). It is clear from the above passages that the word ‘KamarÅ«piya’

â€¢ KamarÅ«panibandha' is pot the name of one work, but that it is a general name for works composed by scholars from Kamarupa.

The MatsyasÅ¯kta is frequently quoted by Raghunandana, as in (vol. I) Tithi. p. 86, MalamÄsa. p. 814, Saá¹skÄra p. 886; (in vol. II.) pp. 61, 69,83 ( several verses ), 141 ( when Stridhvani is Å›ubha Ekadasi pp. 61, 69, 83; Udvaha p. 141.

Brife Note on Works from Kamarupa

983

Six verses from SvalpamatsyapurÄna are cited by Raghu nandana in (vol. II) Chandogavssotsargatattva p. 537 (bearing on

the Sraddba of a man’s father.). For some details about this work, vide Journal of Ganganath Jha Research Institute, vol. IX parts 2-4, November 1953. The first five chapters are only a summary of the first six chapters of the Matsya-purÄÅ†a. The interlocators are God incarnated as Matsya and the hearer is sage Manu.

Recently (in December 1964) Dr. P. C. Choudhury (Direc tor of the Department of Historical and Antiquarian Studies, Assam) published a work edited by Pandit Manoranjan Shastri and himself entitled ‘SmstijyotisasÄra-saigraha’ containing three DharmaÅ›Ästra works from KamarÃ¼pa viz. I. SmstisagarasÄra by DamodaramiÅ›ra (composed in Å›ake 1308 i. e. 1386 A, D.) 76 pages; II GrahaÅ†akaumudi (pp. 79-121 ) by MahÄmahopadhyÄya PitÄm bara-SiddhÄntavÄgisabhattÄcÄrya, the most famous among KamarÃ¼pa writers on DharmaÅ›Ästra (composed in sake 1530 i. e. 1608 A. D.); III. JyotirmÄlÄ (pp. 125â€“163 ) on several astro logical matters by LakÅŸmipati in sake 1613 ( 1691 A. D.).

It appears from the 2nd Introductory verse of the Smrti. sÃ¥garasÄra that it was epitome of a vast work and was condensed as SmstisagarasÄra for the benefit of the sons and pupils of Damodaramisra1638 and it was compiled in sake 1308 (i. e. 1386 A. D.). That it is a mere epitome is made clear in various places by the words vidhistu mÅ«le' p. 43 or Vistarastu mÅ«le (p. 73). It criticizes Nilambara1639 and mentions many works that preceded him, such as Kalpataru (p. 36), JimÃ¼ta vÄhana, RajamÄrtanda (p. 69), and Bá»Šhad-RÄjamÄrtaÅ†da (pp. 63, 65), several PurÄnas etc.

The colophon at the end of Grahana-kaumudi declares that Pitambara was patronized by the king LaksminÄrÄyaá¹‡a of KamarÅ«pa. He quotes numerous authorities and in the Grahana kaumudi he quotes the KÈ™tyacintÄmaÅ†i several times e. g. pp.

1538 GHET HETÃ€ A: HITÃTEL II fartea gasiti praeit

yere gamugar: fefta #91 11 Intro. verses of the mid

à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤°. 1539 à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¥€à¤²à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥ˆà¤•à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤­à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ

FitfoafÃ¼fat i p. 34 of FulTETICHE.

984

History of Dharmasastra

101, 102, 103 and 118). In his Pragjyotisa Souvenir Pandit Manoranjana Sastri points out (on p. 107) that one Pandit

Taranath Goswami of Gauripur mentions 18 works called Kau mudis as composed by Pitambara-VÄgisa, while another Pandit adds ten more Kaumudis, as composed by Pitambara ( in all 28 ) and Pandit Â·Manoranjana Sastri gives his own list of 31 Kau mudis of Pitambara (pp. 108-116 of PrÃ¡gjyotiÅŸa Souvenir ). Pandit Manoranjana Sastri postulates that Pitambara lived for about 90 years from about 1525 to 1615 A. D. (PrÄgjyotisa Sou venir, p. 111).

The printed Smá»™titattva apparently mentions three works called SmstisÄgara, SmstisÄƒgarasÄƒra and Smá»™tisÃ rasagara. This last, is quoted only once by Raghunandana (vol. I Tithi p. 181, three verses) and it appears to the present author a copyist’s mistake (for SmstisagarasÄra ).

Besides these three, there are other KamarÅ«pa writers on DharmaÅ›Ästra, such as VedÄcÃ rya author of a DharmaÅ›Ästra digest called Smsti-ratnÄkara (vide Journal of the Assam Research Society, Hemachandra Goswami Commemoration vol. XIV, 1960 pp. 63-77).

There is a large field for work by KÃ marÃ¼pa scholars on the DharmaÅ›Ästra works composed in Assam during the last seven or eight centuries.

APPENDIX A.

List of Works on DharmaÅ›Ästra It is necessary to say a few words about the methods followed in preparing this list of the works on dharmaÅ›Ästra. Purely srauta works have generally been excluded, except where they have been profusely quoted or relied upon by dharmaÅ›Ästra writers. Works of the Tantra class and the PurÃ Å†as have been passed over, inas-much as they form in themselves independent and extensive branches of Sanskrit literature requiring an exhaustive and detailed treatment, which from considerations of space had to be abandoned here. All individual prayogas, mÄhÄtmyas, vidhis, vratas, Å›Äntis, stotras have been omitted, except where the names of the authors are well-known or there is some importance or peculiarity attaching to them. Purely astrological works on jÄtaka, and tÄjika have not been included, but works of the muhÅ¯rta class that are closely connected with everyday religious practices have been included. Though the gshyasÅ«tras and their commentaries were not dwelt upon in the body of the present work, they have been included in this list as their subject-matter is closely allied to dharmaÅ›Ästra. Only works up to about 1820 A. D. have been entered here. Works on politics ( arthaÅ›Ästra ) have also been included. I am afraid that all the restrictions set out above have not been rigorously observed in the following and crave the indulgence of scholars in this respect. I must gratefully acknowledge, as everyone engaged in preparing a similar list on any branch of post-Vedic literature must do, my indebtedness to the monumental Catalogus Cata logorum of Dr. Aufrecht. But even that catalogue leaves many things doubtful and necessarily gives meagre information. For removing such doubts I was compelled to read and compare the the original catalogues of Sanskrit mss. such as that of the India Office, the Notices of Sanskrit mss. by Dr. Mitra and M. M. Haraprasada. Besides the third part of Aufrecht’s Catalogue was published in 1903. Since then several other catalogues, such as the Descriptive Catalogues and Triennial Catalogues of the Madras Govt. mss. Library, Notices of mss. (new series, part III) by M. M. Haraprasada Å Ästri, Catalogue of Palmleaf and Paper mss. of Nepal Durbar Library by M. M. Haraprasada Å Ästri, Hultzsch’s Report (part III ), Catalogue of Central Provinces Sanskrit mss. by Rai Bahadur Hiralal and Catalogue of the mss. collected by

986

History of Dharmasastra

.

the Bihar and Orissa Govt. (vol. I), have been published. More over I have consulted hundreds of mss. from collections like those at the Deccan College (now in the Bhandarkar 0. R. Institute at Poona), at the AnandÃ¡srama Institution (Poona ), the Bhadkamkar memorial collection started by Prof. H. D. Velankar in Bombay at the Wilson College and the vast collection of the Baroda Oriental Institute. In preparing this list I give, wherever possible and desirable, the names of the authors and of their ancestors, the names of the works quoted by them or of the works that quote them, the age of the work (or of the mss.) their contents &c. In most cases the very name of the work indicates its subject matter. In spite of all this many doubtful points are still left. Various circumstances tend to create con fusion in preparing such lists as are offered here. The same work appears under two, three or even more names in the mss. and the catalogues. Sometimes the names of the authors and even their fathers' names are the same as in the case of DivÄkara, son of Mahadeva and Sankara, son of Nilakantha. Very often portions of a large work appear separately as distinct works in the Catalogues. The same author appears under several forms, as Narasimha and NÈ™sisha, NÄgesa and NÄgoji. I have made great efforts to remove such doubts as far as I could and hope that I have been able to make my own humble contributions to the work so ably done by Aufrecht and others. I do not give references to catalogues in the case of each work, nor do I give all possible references to catalogues against each entry. Only in important cases have 1 given references to catalogues. It has been my endeavour to give earlier references to work and authors wherever I could, than those given by Aufrecht and to find out the age of a work or author by resort to various devices. Only a detailed comparison with Aufrecht can show this, which task I must, in all humility, leave to the readers who will use this list. One more feature of this list to which I wish to draw the attention of the reader is that I have pointed out what works have been printed. In doing this I generally refer only to well-known series and editions like the Bombay Sanskrit series, the Benares Sanskrit series and have not set out editions to which very few can have access. For those who want exhaustive information on this point, the catalogues of printed works in the British Museum Library which have now been brought up to 1928 will be found helpful.

List of Works on DharmaÅ›Ästra

987

Besides the abbreviations given at the beginning of this work, the following abbreviations have been employed in this list and the next.

Maharaja of Bikaner by Rajendralal Mitra (1880). B. O. Cat. - Cat. of mss. collected for the Bihar and Orissa

Government, vol. I. Burnell’s Tanj. Cat. = Classified Index to the Sanskrit mss. in the

palace at Tanjore by Dr. A. C. Burnell (1880). C.-commentary ( of a work under which this letter occurs ). CC. =commentary on a commentary. Ch. S. Series =Chowkhamba Sanskrit Series. com,=commentary or commentator, according to context. C. P. cat. = Catalogue of Sanskrit and Prakrit mss. in the Central

Provinces and Berar, by Rai Bahadur Hiralal (1926,

Dr. Hultzsch, parts I-III. Jivananda sm. =collection of smstis edited by Jivananda in two

parts. m.=mentioned (by or in ).

à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤—à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤°à¥ by à¤œà¤—à¤¨à¤¾à¤¥. pp. 2-4

à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤°à¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤ª by à¤—à¥Œà¤°à¥€à¤¶à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ à¤…à¤¦à¥à¤­à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤• by à¤®à¤¹à¥€à¤§à¤°.

( new series) vol. III. preface | à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤ª (Stein p. 82). p. IX and p. 8.

à¤†à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¶à¥à¤°

à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾. à¤†à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾.

à¤­à¤¾à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤—à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤§à¤°à¥€ by à¤—à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤§à¤°. à¤†à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹.

à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾. à¤†à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿ (in verse in 10 | à¤†à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ by à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤¾à¤¯, son of

yananda,

à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ ( Stein’s cat. p. 83 ). à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿, quoted by à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡

à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ by à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¤à¤•à¤‚à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥€à¤¶. à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°, à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿, à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤µ, à¤¹à¤°à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤¤.

some work of à¤µà¥‡à¤™à¥à¤•à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤¶.

à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°. before 1500 A. D.

à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤° by à¤¬à¤²à¤­à¤¦à¥à¤°. à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ (from à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤•à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¿) à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤.

by à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¥à¤µà¥€à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°.

à¤†à¤¶à¥‹à¤šà¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤šà¤®à¤à¥à¤œà¤°à¥€.

| rainfall ). Baroda O. I. 11047

à¤‹à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥ƒà¤™à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿- vide see. 40. à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿. à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ by à¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¤®à¥à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ alias à¤¬à¤¾à¤²- à¤à¤•à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿ by à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•.

à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤£à¥à¤¡; ms. dated à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤¨à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¤¨à¤¨à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤—à¤°à¥à¤— ( Baroda 1848 (1792 A. D.) in Stein’s ___0. I. No. 5661). cat. p. 302.

SON

à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨.

à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥€à¤¯à¥‚à¤· m. in à¤…à¤¹à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿.

à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ by à¤•à¤²à¤¾à¤¯à¤–à¤¾. à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¥‡à¤§à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨ ( from à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¤).

à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ m. by à¤°à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨ in à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿.

à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µ. à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¯ ( Baroda 0. I. | à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ of à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤° à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¥ (on

à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿, à¤¶à¥‚à¤²à¤—à¤µ). à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ by à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤°à¤¾à¤®. à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤ª attributed to à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¨ or à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤•à¥Œà¤®à¥à¤¦à¥€ by à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤¤, son of à¤†à¤µà¤¸.

Later than 1680

(Haibatrao) in 20 fine verses A. D.

à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤ª or à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯ by à¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤• by à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ son of à¤¨à¥€à¤²à¤•à¤£à¥à¤  | à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯.

of the à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤§à¤° family; pr. at

à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤•à¤° by à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°. Ratnagiri in 1873.

à¤•à¥à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ of à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¿. C. à¤®à¤°à¥€à¤šà¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤²à¤¾ by à¤°à¤˜à¥à¤µà¥€à¤°, son of à¤µà¤¿à¤ à¥à¤ à¤² who was author of

à¤•à¥à¤¶à¤•à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ by à¤µà¤‚à¤¶à¥€à¤§à¤°. à¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤ªà¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿; pr. at Bom. à¤•à¥‚à¤ªà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾. bay in 1902. He wrote à¤•à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¹à¥‹à¤®. à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤° in 1635-36 A. D.

à¤•à¥‚à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¹à¥‹à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—. à¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤•à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¿à¤•à¤¾ by à¤¬à¤²à¤­à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¤¿. à¤•à¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£.

C. by author.

à¤•à¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤—. à¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µ by à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤§à¤° à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¨à¥, son of | à¤•à¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°,

à¤°à¤¾à¤® (Stein’s Cat. p. 87). à¤•à¥Œà¤·à¥€à¤¤à¤•à¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤° (pr. in Ben. Vide under à¤¶à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¨- à¤ªà¤°à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤® (Stein’s Cat. p. 87). à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°.

_O. I. 8789). à¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡ (taken from à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤§à¥).

à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤¯à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ƒà¤°à¤¾à¤œ. à¤—à¥Œà¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿.

à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ ( Peterson’s 5th à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œ or à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œ

__Report p. 98). à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤•à¥à¤¸à¥à¤® by à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¶à¤®à¤¨à¥. à¥¤ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯ or à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯ (from à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®.

à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£). à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ).

cutta o. Series No. 2, 1921 ). !

author of à¤†à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤• ( both being à¤¤à¤¿à¤¥à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤–à¤° by à¤¨à¤¾à¤—à¥‹à¤œà¥€à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ parts of à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¿). CHOTI

History of Dharmasastra

à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥€, à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾, à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿, à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¨à¥, à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹- à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ m. in. à¤¨à¤¿. à¤¸à¤¿. and à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤, à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿, à¤¦à¥‚à¤¤, à¤šà¤¾à¤°, à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°, à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤­ of à¤…à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤¨, à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‡à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤¯ ( à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¿ &c. ),

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

Cat. p. 137 says so, but it à¤µà¥ˆà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¾à¤¥ ( from his à¤¸à¤•à¤²à¤¾à¤—à¤®à¤¸à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹.) |

appears that à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤²à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¤¿ is a à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¿à¤•à¤¾ by à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¤¿à¤¨à¥€à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿.

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

.

à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¿à¤¨à¥€ by à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¤–à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤‚à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹ by à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ; men

à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤°à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ by à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤œ. à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤šà¥‚à¤¡à¤¾à¤®à¤£à¤¿ by à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤œà¥à¤, son of | à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤­à¥‚à¤·à¤£ or -à¤®à¤à¥à¤œà¥€à¤° by à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥‡à¤µà¤•

à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤œà¥à¤ of à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤œà¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°.

à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨ (N.vol. XI preface p. 4). à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ by à¤•à¥‡à¤¶à¤µ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤œà¥à¤, son of |

pupil of à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¹à¤‚à¤¸à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤•à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯- à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤šà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤£à¤¿ or à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¨ in 5 à¤ªà¤Ÿà¤²s ( D. 1106

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

1

above. Bik. Cat. p. 497 No. and 65 ) dated à¤². à¤¸à¤‚. 372 i.e. 1490-91. This is different from

(p. 291).

(à¤à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¿à¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¤•à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ of à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ.

à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤—à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤®à¥¤) à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤®à¥€à¤®à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¾ by à¤…à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤®.

à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯ by à¤°à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¥à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤° in 109 verses divided into five chapters on à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°,

à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤œà¤¨à¤¨à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤•à¤®à¤²à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¿à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®, à¤†à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤®, à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤œà¥à¤¯, à¤°à¤¾à¤œ

à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ª. à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤—à¤®à¤®à¤à¥à¤œà¤°à¥€ by à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£- | à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤£ by à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¶à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾, son of

and rules, such as fafueray, à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¿ by à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ, son à¤®à¤²à¤®à¤¾à¤¸, à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿, à¤†à¤¶à¥Œà¤š, à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§,

| à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¯ by à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯; m. à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¯ m. in à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ by à¤Ÿà¥‹à¤¡à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦, à¤¨à¤¿.à¤¸à¤¿., à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µ,

1

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µ m. in à¤¨à¤¿. à¤¸à¤¿., à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°- à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤­à¤¦à¥à¤°, son of à¤­à¥ˆà¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°, ruled

à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°. à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤¯à¥‹à¤— (à¥© à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£s).

à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤•à¥à¤°à¤® by à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤šà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ by à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯

(Baroda. O. I. 10057 ). à¤‹à¤—à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾ and à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾).

1154

History of DharmaÅ›Ästra

à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤²à¤¿ by à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤š (1) by à¤›à¤²à¤¾à¤°à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£, m. by

à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿. Composed in 1657 A.D.; his son in à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°. vide under à¤¦à¤¾à¤¯à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤•. Stein’s |

(2) by à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤® Cat. p. 109.

à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤­à¤°.

APPENDIX B

LIST OF AUTHORS ON DHARMASÃSTRA

While preparing this list, great difficulties were experienced in stating all the works composed by an author. In the case of such names as Ananta, Krsna, Gangadhara, NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, Rama kÄ¼ÅŸÅ†a, Sankara which are extremely common, the only method that could be followed, in the absence of materials to identify the authors bearing these names, was to place the same name several times in the list against the work composed by that author. Since the authors themselves very often convey no more informa tion than their own names and since some of the reports on the search for mss. do not give even what little information about the author can be gathered from the ms. of his work, Aufrecht also was compelled to follow this method. In order to avoid repetition and save space, I have not repeated in this list the in formation that was given under the works contained in the list A. Dates are given principally under the names of authors and sometimes under works also. For further information readers will have in many cases to refer to the works put down as com posed by an author. In the case of authors who have written on several sastras, their works on dharmaÅ›Ästra alone have been mentioned. Wherever possible parentage has been noted and dates assigned. In a few cases information which became avail able after list A was prepared has been incorporated here.

1160

Alstory of DharmaÅ›Ästra

in à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤° of à¤•à¥à¤²à¥à¤²à¤•à¤­à¤Ÿà¥à¤Ÿ, in à¤¶à¥‚à¤²- | à¤œà¥‹à¤—à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•- vide à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•. à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿’ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤• and à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤ | à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤° a. of à¤†à¤¹à¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤ª and à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤• by à¤°à¤˜à¥à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨ in à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ | à¤†à¤¹à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤•.

à¤¸à¥à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¿à¤¨à¥€ ( com, on the à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾ Mss. Cat. vol. I. No. 445 of à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° ), à¤®à¤¦à¤¨à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¤, à¤®à¤¹à¤¾ p. 521 ).
